column3937: She had been on, or rather under known ground on the Piccadilly Railway as far as Leicester Square, but after that she had not heard, or else had forgotten, that in order to get to Hampstead by the train into which she had stepped she must change at Camden Town.
column3938: Or perhaps she had merely wondered what Camden Town supposed itself to be that she should put herself to the trouble of changing there.
column3939: With the newspaper held at arm's length, and a little figure-8-shaped gold glass moving slightly between her puckered old eyes and the page, she was reading the "_By the Way_" column of the "Globe."
column3940: --"All change," called the man at Highgate; and, still unconscious of her mistake, Lady Tasker left the train.
column3941: She was the last to enter the lift.
column3942: But for an unhurried raising of the little locket-shaped glass as the attendant fidgeted at the half-closed gate she might have been the first to enter the next lift.
column3943: Only from the policeman outside Highgate Station did she learn that she must either take the Tube back again to Camden Town or else walk across the Heath.
column3944: Now Lady Tasker was seventy, and, with the exception of the Zoo, a place she visited from time to time with troops of turbulent great-nephews, the whole of North London was a sort of Camden Town to her, that is to say, she had no objection to its existence so long as it wasn't troublesome.
column3945: It was half-past three when she said as much to the Highgate policeman, who up to that time had been an ordinary easy-going Conservative; by five-and-twenty minutes to four she had made of him a fuming Radical.
column3946: He was saying something about South Square and Merton Lane.
column3947: Lady Tasker addressed the bracing Highgate air in one of those expressionless and semi-ventriloquial asides that, especially in a mixed company, always made her ladyship very well worth sitting next to.
column3949: Does the man suppose that conveys anything to me?....
column3950: I want to know how to get to Hampstead, not the names of the objects of interest on the way!"

column3952: It was a wonder that Lady Tasker's glare, focussed through the gold-rimmed glass on a point between his shoulder-blades, did not burn a hole in his tunic.
column3953: Taxis at eightpence a mile, indeed, with the house at Ludlow already full of those children of Churchill's, and three of Tony's little girls eating their way through the larder in Cromwell Gardens, and young Tommy, Emily's boy, who had just "pulled" his captaincy, arriving at Southampton in the "Seringapatam" on Saturday with another batch for her to take under her wing!
column3954: Did people suppose she was made of money?...
column3955: The policeman's tunic was just beginning to scorch when Lady Tasker, dropping the glass, turned away and set out for Hampstead on foot.
column3956: She might very well have been excused had she omitted to return Mrs. Cosimo Pratt's call.
column3957: Indeed she had vowed that very morning that nothing should drag her up to Hampstead that day.
column3958: But for twenty times that Lady Tasker said "I will not," nineteen she repented and went, taking out the small change of her magnanimity when she got there.
column3959: And after all, she would be killing two birds with one stone, for her niece Dorothy also lived somewhere in this northern Great Karroo, and unless she got these things over before the "Seringapatam" dropped anchor on Saturday there was no knowing when next she would have an hour to call her own.
column3960: As she turned (after a brush with a second policeman, who summed her up quite wrongly on the strength of her antiquated pelisse and trailing old Victorian hat) down Merton Lane to the ponds, she told herself again that she was a foolish old woman to have come at all.
column3961: For the Cosimo Pratts were not bosom friends of hers.
column3962: True, they had been, until six months ago, her neighbours at Ludlow, and for that matter she had known young Cosimo's people for the greater part of her life: but she had not forgotten the hearty blackguarding the young couple had got, any time this last two years, from the rest of the country-side.
column3964: What else did they expect, after the way in which they had made farm-labour too big for its jacket and beaters hardly to be had for love or money?
column3965: Not that Lady Tasker herself had seen very much of their antics.
column3966: Great-nieces and nephews had kept her too busy for that, and she was moreover wise enough not to believe all she heard.
column3967: And even were it true, that, she now told herself, had been in the country.
column3968: They would have to behave differently now that they had let the Shropshire house and had come to live in town.
column3969: They could hardly dance barefoot round a maypole in Hampstead, or stage-manage the yearly Hiring-Fair for the sake of the "Daily Speculum" photographer (as they had done in Ludlow), or group themselves picturesquely about the feet of the oldest inhabitant while that shocking old reprobate with the splendid head recited (at five shillings an hour) the stories of old, unhappy, far-off things he had learned by heart from the booklets they had printed at the Village Press.
column3970: No: in London they would almost certainly have to do as other people did, and Shropshire, after its three years of social and artistic awakening, would no doubt forget all about the æsthetic revival and would sink back into a well-earned rest.
column3971: It was a Thursday afternoon in September, warm for the time of the year, and a half-day closing for the shops.
column3972: Had Lady Tasker remembered the half-holiday she certainly would not have come.
column3973: She hated crowds, and, if you would believe her, had no illusions whatever about the sanctity of our common nature and the brotherhood of man.
column3974: She would tell you roundly that there was far too much aimless good-nature in the world, and that every sob wasted over a sinner was something taken away from the man who, if he was a sinner too, had at least the decency to keep up appearances.
column3976: Great-nephewship, of course, was another matter.
column3977: Somebody had to look after all those youngsters, and if her sister Eliza, the one at Spurrs, went into a tantrum about every bud that was picked in the gardens and every chair-leg that was an inch out of its place in the house, so much the worse for Lady Tasker, who must walk because she had something else to do with her money than to waste it on taxis.
column3978: She had been told by her niece Dorothy to look out for a clump of tall willows and an ivied chimney; that was where the Pratts lived; but Dorothy had spoken of the approach from the Hampstead side, not from Highgate way.
column3980: She was almost dropping for want of a cup of tea, and the Heath seemed all willows, and all the wrong ones.
column3981: No policeman, Radical or Conservative, was to be seen.
column3982: Walking across an apparently empty space, well away (as she thought) from a horde of shouting boys, the old lady suddenly found herself enveloped in a game of football.
column3984: Near by, one of Messrs. Libertys' carts was ascending a steep road at a slow walk; somehow or other Lady Tasker managed to get her hand on the tail of it; and the car gave her a tow.
column3986: As it happened, that was her first piece of luck in a luckless afternoon.
column3987: The cart drew on to the left; Lady Tasker trailed after it; and suddenly it stopped before a high privet hedge with a closed green door in the middle of it.
column3988: Lady Tasker did not look for the ivied chimney.

column3991: Ordinarily Lady Tasker would have approved of the height of the privet hedge, which was seven or eight feet; that was a nice, reassuring, anti-social height for a hedge; but as it was she could not even put up her hand to the bell.

column4012: Now in reading what happened the next moment you must remember that Lady Tasker was very, very tired.
column4013: Had she been less tired she might have wondered why one of the two maids she saw crossing to the tea-table under the copper beech had not been allowed to take in Mrs. Cosimo Pratt's parcel.
column4014: And she would certainly have thought it extraordinary that she should be left standing alone while Mrs. Cosimo Pratt scolded the carrier, and wanted to know why the parcel had not been brought yesterday.
column4015: But, tired as she was, her eyes had already rested on something that had momentarily galvanized even the weariness out of her.
column4016: It was this:-- Seven or eight people sat in basket-chairs or stood talking; and, under the copper beech, as if Mrs. Pratt had just slid out of it, a hammock of coloured string still moved, slung from the beech to a sycamore beyond.
column4017: Lady Tasker saw these things at once; she did not at once see what it was that stood just beyond the hammock.
column4018: Then it moved, and Lady Tasker raised her glass.
column4019: No doubt you have seen the cover of Mr. Wells's "Invisible Man."
column4020: It will be remembered that all that can be seen of that afflicted person is his clothes; and all that Lady Tasker at first saw of the Invisible Man by the copper beech was his clothes.
column4021: These were of light yellow tussore, with a white double collar and a small red tie, sharp-edged white cuffs and highly polished brown boots.
column4022: At collar and cuffs the man ended.
